awd_titl_txt: CC*DNI Integration (Area 4): Application Aware Software-Defined Networks for Secure Cloud Services (SecureCloud)
awd_abstract_narration:
The Application-Aware, Software-Defined Networks for Secure Cloud Services (SecureCloud) project designs and builds an innovative cyberinfrastructure for cloud computing networks and enhancing data security without degrading network performance.  SecureCloud is a response to the growth of new, highly sophisticated cybersecurity threats that have accompanied the emergence of cloud computing and placed national cybersecurity infrastructure at risk. Cyber attacks are responsible for a range of recent problems ranging from theft of personal information and interfering with financial transactions to threatening national security and government operations.

SecureCloud is studying 1) how to minimize the impact of multi-component malware infiltration and 2) how to improve threat visibility and response time. The project develops, tests, and deploys a fully automated security system that is implemented throughout the cloud infrastructure. The system is prototyped in a software-defined networking (SDN) test bed at Marist College, and first deployed into production across regional and New York State-wide networks. SecureCloud uses SDN to dynamically re-provision network resources in response to impending attacks.  The infrastructure includes control of virtual network functions such as virtual router/firewall combinations, traffic flow segregation in metropolitan area networks, and integration of threat intelligence from other data sources using network traffic analytics.  The overarching goals are to 1) enable new network functionality to protect networks from malware and denial of service attacks; 2) improve visibility and response time to security threats, 3) quarantine infected computers, and 4) contribute new open source software to the community for integration with a wide range of applications.

por.por_cntn:
Cybersecurity for cloud computing systems has become a significant problem, since both the number and severity of cyber-threats grows with each passing year. This project developed an autonomic, zero trust test bed to secure cloud computing environments at the Marist College NY State Cloud Computing and Analytic Center (CCAC).  We constructed a test bed including over 100 km of optical fiber interconnecting three virtual data centers. We then wrote and tested software to perform a variety of functions. This included LCARS (Lightweight Cloud Application for Real Time Security), a security dashboard, analytic engine, and orchestrator capable of detecting attacks, classifying attacks, and automatically adjusting firewalls, routers, or other devices to mitigate attacks. In order to collect data on attacks, we wrote the first (to the best of our knowledge) honeypot which mimics a software defined network (SND) network controller and measured its performance/server response time.  Preliminary measurements indicate up to 20% performance improvement when implementing our security architecture vs conventional methods. We also wrote a REST API honeypot for graph databases, which has successfully identified signature-based attacks against our deployment using an Amazon Web Services instance.We demonstrated network segmentation and authentication using transport access control (TAC) and first packet authentication techniques (forming the building block of a zero trust network).  We demonstrated quarantine of attacking malware and dynamic trust policy adjustment using log parsing from the authentication appliance, policy-based orchestration, and dynamic control plane feedback to our SDN appliances. We applied machine learning algorithms (C4.5, Bayesian Network, Decision Table, and Naive-Bayes) trained on historical network attack data, to identify potential malicious connections and potential attack destinations, and to predict hosts that will be attacked with over 90% accuracy. We tested use cases including distributed denial of service (DDoS) with malware insertion, with the aid of our Internet of Things (IoT) lab to simulate botnet attacks. Forensic analysis was performed on these attacks in order to improve our system performance, with support from our Security Operations Center (SOC). We then completed pre-production testing and deployed our results into the Marist CCAC network, as well as the IBM LinuxOne cloud environment.  This project trained a diverse group of undergraduate students, who have been recognized for their work with best paper awards from venues such as the NY IT conference and IBM TechConnect conference. 

 


Last Modified: 01/31/2019
Modified by: Casimer Decusatis
